entry.title: Lam: Never in it
entry.summary:
Adrian Lam reacts to Wigan's defeat to Catalans Dragons.

The post Lam: Never in it appeared first on Wigan Warriors Blog.
entry.content:
• Adrian Lam reacts to Wigan’s defeat to Catalans Dragons.
  • Lam: “Better opposition punish you, like they did today.”
  • FT | Catalans Dragons 48-0 Wigan Warriors.

Adrian Lam pointed to the continual mistakes made by his side being the key to their away defeat to Catalans Dragons on Saturday.

Wigan’s unbeaten run of seven games in the league came to a halt at the hands of the French side, as Steve McNamara’s men put on eight unanswered tries at Stade Gilbert Brutus.

Speaking to the media shortly after the final whistle, Lamgave his immediate reaction to the result.

“I thought Catalans were very good, they completed high and exectued their game plan.

“I thought we were really poor, from the start were were never really in the game at all.”

The head coach highlighted how mistakes from Wigan were their undoing.

“We had opportunities early but again our mistakes came, and better opposition punish you, like they did today.

“Everything we did went against us. We make errors early and from that point we never got better.”

The game ended in disapointing circumstances as Zak Hardaker was handed a red card following a coming-together with his opposing full back Sam Tomkins. Catalans’ Joel Tomkins was then handed a yellow card for his follow up in the ugly scenes that followed.

On the moment, Lam said: “I need to have another look at it. However, being red-carded in the last minute for that is unacceptable.

“Iâ€™m not sure how bad it is, but it was a really poor end to the game.”

Wigan are next in action on Friday 11th June, as they travel away to face Huddersfield Giants.

With almost two weeks between Saturday’s defeat and the Warriors’ next outing, Lam said there are positives and negatives to the break.

“It’s a challenge now for the group to respond in two weeks time.

“it gives those players with niggling injuries time to get over them, but equally we’d like to be back out there next weekend if we could and put things right.”

entry.title: Warriors lose in Perpignan
entry.summary:
Match report as Wigan Warriors lose to Catalans Dragons.

The post Warriors lose in Perpignan appeared first on Wigan Warriors Blog.
entry.content:
• Match report as Wigan Warriors lose to Catalans Dragons.
  • Wigan’s winning start to the 2021 Super League season came to an end away in France.
  • FT | Catalans Dragons 48-0 Wigan Warriors.

Wigan’s unbeaten start to the 2021 Betfred Super League season came to an end at the hands of Catalans Dragons in Perpignan on Saturday evening.

Eight unanswered tries for the French side saw Steve McNamara’s side win 48-0 in front of a limited crowd.

The home side got the scoreboard ticking over early, when ex-Wiganer Michael McIlorum crossed for the French side in the sixth minute.

Catalans struck again in the 18th minute, and again the score came from an ex-Wigan player. A grubber from Josh Drinkwater found the run of Sam Tomkins to touch down.

The full back grabbed a second on the stroke of half time, diving over in the corner, taking the scores to 16-0 after Maloney missed the following conversion attempt.

Steve McNamaraâ€™s men extended their lead shortly after half time, when Maloney converted a penalty given for a high tackle on Arthur Mourgue.

Mourgue turned scorer in the 52nd, stepping inside his marker and crossing for his first Super League try.

Drinkwater grabbed a score in the 55th, chasing his own grubber on the last to touch down.

The half back got his second of the game just three minutes later, dummying a pass out left and ducking inside to Warriors markers to score.

Mike McMckeen added a seventh for the home side in the 62nd, assisted by winger Tom Davies.

Mathieu Laguerre rounded off the win for Catalans, going over in the corner with five minutes left on the clock.

The game ended in a disappointing fashion, as a coming together saw Zak Hardaker given a red card for leading with his head on Sam Tomkins, while Joel Tomkins’ retaliation saw him served with a yellow.

Catalans Dragons: Sam Tomkins, Tom Davies, Dean, Whare, Samisoni Langi, Mathieu, Laguerre, James Maloney, Josh Drinkwater, Julian Bousquet, Michael McIlorum, Gill Dudson, Michael McMeeken, Benjamin Jullien, Benjamin Garcia.

Goals: Maloney (7/8)

Penalties: Maloney (48′)

Yellow Card: J. Tomkins (79′)

Wigan Warriors: Zak Hardaker, Dom Manfredi, Jake Bibby, Liam Farrell, Umyla Hanley, Tommy Leuluai, Jackson Hastings, Brad Singleton, Sam Powell, Ethan Havard, Morgan Smithies, John Bateman, Oliver Partington.

entry.content:
Wigan Warriors can confirm that centre Oliver Gildart will leave the Club at the end of the 2021 season to join Wests Tigers.

A product of the Wigan Academy, Gildart, 24, has been a first team regular since 2016 â€“ making 129 appearances and scoring 61 tries for his hometown Club.  

The Great Britain and England international is a double Super League winner with Wigan and was also part of the World Club Challenge triumph in 2017.  

Wigan Warriors executive director, Kris Radlinski, said: “Oliver has made it clear for a number of years that he has an NRL ambition. He has honoured his contact and has served the Club and the town tremendously well.  

“Young players come to us at 14 years of age and you watch them transition into men. The development journey takes you through many highs and lows and there is always a sense of pride when they achieve their goals.

“Oliver should be very proud of what he has achieved at Wigan and in Super League. We wish him well in the next stages of his career and life.”

Gildart said: “Iâ€™ve been living my childhood dream playing for my hometown club since the age of 11. 

“Iâ€™ll never forget my debut try against Warrington and of course, it doesnâ€™t get much better than playing in front of a packed Old Trafford and scoring a try in a Grand Final win.

“Iâ€™ve had the privilege of being surrounded by legends year in year out at this Club who have helped me become the person l am today.

“However, itâ€™s been no secret that Iâ€™ve wanted to challenge myself over in Australia. When Michael Maguire and his team showed interest, it became clear that Wests Tigers is where I want to be in the next stage of my career.

“I owe a lot of credit to my dad, Bill Ashurst and Alan Rimmer for pushing me on in my amateur days at Wigan St Pats.

“And a massive thanks to the fans. You have been outstanding through thick and thin. We canâ€™t wait to have you back in the stands.

“With that said, there is unfinished business to take care of for Wigan this season. 

“My priority is to get back to playing my best rugby in Cherry and White and finish the season off with another Grand Final ring in front of the fans.”

entry.title: LLW Legends series: Sean Oâ€™Loughlin
entry.summary:
Part Three is now available to watch

The post LLW Legends series: Sean Oâ€™Loughlin appeared first on Wigan Warriors Blog.
entry.content:
• New Loch Lomond Whiskies Legends interview series launches with Sean Oâ€™Loughlin as the first guest.
  • Kris Radlinski to sit down with a number of Club legends as part of the new content series.
  • Watch Part One, Part Two and Part Three of the interview with Oâ€™Loughlin below.

Wigan Warriors are delighted to launch a new interview series â€“ Loch Lomond Whiskies Legends â€“ as Sean Oâ€™Loughlin sits down with Kris Radlinski to discuss his career at his hometown Club. 

In the #SpritOfTheWarriors, the series will see executive director Radlinski chat with a number of Club legends to discuss their time at Wigan Warriors.

Our first interview is with former Club captain, Sean Oâ€™Loughlin. Watch Part One, Part Two and Part Three below.

In Part One of the interview, Oâ€™Loughlin reflects on the 2020 Super League Grand Final, managing the process of retirement, his relationship with Tommy Leuluai and Liam Farrell, what itâ€™s like to be in illustrious company with the great captains gone by and the role of leadership. Radlinski and Oâ€™Loughlin also try an 18-year-old bottle of Loch Lomond whisky!

In Part Two, the conversation turns to coaching as Oâ€™Loughlin reflects on the past four months in his first stint as an assistant coach. He talks about the intensity of being a coach compared to a player and the mental fatigue that comes with it, still being able to have interaction with players by running messages on the pitch on game day and what his coaching philosophy could look like in the future. 

Oâ€™Loughlin also discusses how he is using personal strengths of past coaches in his own coaching methods, adapting to an ever-changing workplace in modern day society, as well as his long-term coaching ambitions and learning the trade of a coach at Wigan. 

Part Three sees O’Loughlin reflect on his 19-year career with his hometown club. He talks about how he feels his game and the sport changed over the years, as well as the role of the No.13 position. After playing 459 games and ten major trophies for Wigan, O’Loughlin describes how his body is feeling now, the relief of winning the 2010 Super League Grand Final and of having no regret of playing in the NRL. He also looks back at his career highlights and memorable moments.

The conversation then moves to the sport in general and O’Loughlin’s hopes of there being more hunger from fans to watch Rugby League post-Covid-19. He also explains about what the sport can do to sell itself more and to have more eyes watching it, as well as stating England’s chances of winning the 2021 World Cup under his former coach Shaun Wane.

Make sure to stay tuned for the next Loch Lomond Whiskies interview as another Wigan Warriors legend will sit down with Kris Radlinski to discuss their career with the Club.
